awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Manufacturing USA: Determining the Role of Nanoscale Physics in the Microscale Selective Laser Sintering Process using a Multiscale Computational Modeling Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Flexible electronic devices are of great interest due to the rapid expansion of wearable devices for health monitoring and the rise of the Internet-of-Things. One key factor limiting their development is the integration of diverse high-quality, silicon-based electrical components with flexible substrates. This integration is difficult because the small electrical connections needed to interface the silicon chips with flexible substrates cannot be fabricated using existing manufacturing processes. A new process called microscale selective laser sintering (microscale-SLS) has been developed which offers the potential to overcome this manufacturing limitation by successfully sintering (fusing) nanoscale particles to create complex, three-dimensional, metal parts with micron-scale resolution on almost any substrate. Currently the commercial viability of the process is limited by a lack of understanding of the underlying physics governing the sintering process, and an inability to accurately model the process outcomes. This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research project will overcome this limitation by developing fundamental science regarding the impact of nanoscale physics on the mass and energy transfer within the microscale-SLS process, and ultimately the final part integrity. As this project is an industry-university collaborative effort between NXP USA and the University of Texas Austin (UTA), it will provide both educational experiences and industrial traineeships for graduate and undergraduate students. A particular focus on providing opportunities and training to students from underrepresented backgrounds in engineering will be pursued through senior design projects and the Nanomanufacturing Systems for Mobile Computing and Mobile Energy Technologies (NASCENT) Center's High School Fellows program.

The research objective of the project is to understand the fundamental science regarding mechanisms by which thin layers of nanoparticles (NPs) are selectively laser sintered to realize 3D structures with resolutions of  around  one micron. The central hypothesis is that nanoscale effects such as surface diffusion, near-field radiation, and light scattering dominate the part-formation process in microscale-SLS, and therefore must be considered to accurately model microscale-SLS part formation. The specific aims of this project are to determine the mechanisms for (1) NP reshaping during the microscale-SLS process, (2) light penetration/absorption in the NP powder bed, and (3) heat transfer within the NP powder bed, and (4) to determine the relationship between NP-level mechanisms and continuum-level parameters for modeling part formation. A multiscale computational modeling approach for the macroscale selective laser sintering process (MCM-SLS) will be leveraged to construct a model of the microscale-SLS part formation process. It is expected that the development of accurate models of the microscale-SLS process will have a positive impact on the manufacturing of three-dimensional microscale interconnect structures by (1) reducing the time required to determine the optimal process parameters for microscale-SLS parts, (2) improving the scientific understanding of how part design affects part quality/yield, and (3) allowing designers to estimate part quality (strength, shape, conductivity, etc.) before fabrication. The computational models will be validated in collaboration with NXP USA using a prototype microscale-SLS system at their facilities.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

During the process of laser sintering, the particles underneath the laser heat up. Since these particles are touching other colder particles, heat spreads outward from the spot of laser application via conduction between particles. This heat spread often makes it more difficult to predict the shape of parts that result from laser sintering. To address this issue, heat transfer simulations have been developed to estimate the ability of a powder bed to spread out heat during laser sintering (represented as the thermal conductivity of the powder bed). Prior to this point, such thermal conductivity simulations for nanoparticles undergoing sintering did not exist and so it was necessary to build such simulations for this process. These simulations analyze small groups of particles to determine their thermal conductivity. Since particles fuse together when heated, the geometry of these particle groups changes significantly during the sintering process. As such, to understand the changes in thermal conductivity of the bed, it was important to first understand how the geometry of the particles change when heated. Prior work done by researchers in this field showed ways of modelling and simulating the changes that take place in the geometry of a handful of nanoparticles placed either right next to each other, or in an ordered structure in a cube. No work had been done in this field to understand how more than twenty nanoparticles, randomly located in a powder bed, would reshape when heated. This project has created simulations to bridge that gap. 

Under this work, novel simulations have been made to predict the arrangement of nanoparticles deposited onto a flat surface, as well as onto previous layers of sintered and unsintered nanoparticles. The number of nanoparticles in these generated beds have ranged from twenty to over a hundred. To understand how these nanoparticles behave when heat is added to the system, new simulations were built to predict changes in the shapes and connections that form between particles. These simulations have been capable of predicting the reshaping of particles in a bed containing over a hundred nanoparticles, which had not previously been done. To validate these simulations actual nanoparticles were heated in a furnace and the changes in density was measured and compared against the predictions from the simulations. As particles reshape, the empty spaces (pores) between the particles prior to heat application start to go away as the particles connect and begin to fuse together. This fusion leads to increases in density as the nanoparticles are heated for longer times. It was necessary to perform such experiments, because no such quantification had been previously done. The comparison of the results found showed good correlation between the changes in density predicted from the simulations and measured in the experiments. 

Once a full understanding was gained of how the geometry of particles in the bed changes during heating, it was then possible to quantify the heat spread throughout this sintering process, using the heat transfer simulations. Therefore, the heat transfer simulations were used to determine the thermal conductivity right before the start of sintering, during sintering, and at the end of sintering. Simulation results were collected and used to determine the relationship between thermal conductivity and the amount of sintering that has occurred. 

 

Broader impact:

This project helped in training the next generation of manufacturing engineers and scientists to apply novel computational tools to understand physical interactions in novel semiconductor manufacturing processes. In addition to supervising and training several graduate students, the PI managed and advised undergraduate and high-school students working on different aspects of this project through the UT senior design program, NASCENT Research Experiences of Undergraduates (REU) program and other programs involving Austin-area high school students. Additionally, outreach activities for improving participation from underrepresented minorities were successfully undertaken leveraging UT Austin’s Freshman Research Initiative (FRI) and Freshman Introduction to Research in Engineering (FIRE) programs.

The key results from this project helped in the development of robust simulation and validation models of the previously unknown micro/nanoscale physical systems. These simulation models combined with the experimental tools led to the spin-out of a semiconductor packaging company, Texas MicroSintering, LLC. The primary mission of the company is to be the technology driver for the next generation of chip packaging for an integrated and connected future. 


Last Modified: 08/31/2021
Modified by: Michael Cullinan
